In Julia, Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

In Julia, you can use the `Dates` module to manipulate date and time data types. Here is how you could implement this function:

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map(x -> DateFormat("yyyymm")(x), df[:dt])
end
```

In the function `add_yearmonth`, we use the `map` function to apply a transformation (extracting year and month from date time and concatenating them) to every element in the column `:dt` of DataFrame `df`. The result is then assigned back to the new column `:ym`. 

The DateFormat("yyyymm")(x) part extracts the year and month from a DateTime `x` using "yyyymm" format. This returns an integer in the format “yyyymm”.
